squidpony.squidmath

Class WhirlingNoise

  • java.lang.Object
    • squidpony.squidmath.PerlinNoise
      • squidpony.squidmath.WhirlingNoise
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Noise.Noise2D, Noise.Noise3D, Noise.Noise4D

    @Beta
public class WhirlingNoise
extends PerlinNoise
implements Noise.Noise2D, Noise.Noise3D, Noise.Noise4D
    Another experimental noise class. Extends PerlinNoise and should have similar quality, but can be faster and has less periodic results. This is still considered experimental because the exact output may change in future versions, along with the scale (potentially) and the parameters it takes. In general, noise(double, double) and noise(double, double, double) should have similar appearance to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double), but are not forced to a zoomed-in scale like PerlinNoise makes its results, are less likely to repeat sections of noise, and are also somewhat faster (a 20% speedup can be expected over PerlinNoise using those two methods). Sound good?
    Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/14/2016.

      • grad3f

        protected static final float[][] grad3f
        The 32 3D vertices of a rhombic triacontahedron. These specific values were taken from Vladimir Bulatov's stellation applet, which has available source but is unlicensed, and is available here, but the vertices are mathematical constants so copyright isn't an issue.

      • grad4f

        protected static final float[][] grad4f

      • getNoise

        public double getNoise(double x,
                       double y)
        2D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Specified by:
        getNoise in interface Noise.Noise2D
        Parameters:
        x - X input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        y - Y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • getNoiseWithSeed

        public double getNoiseWithSeed(double x,
                               double y,
                               int seed)
        Identical to getNoise(double, double); ignores seed.
        Specified by:
        getNoiseWithSeed in interface Noise.Noise2D
        Parameters:
        x - X input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        y - Y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        seed - ignored entirely.
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

        public double getNoise(double x,

        3D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Specified by:
        getNoise in interface Noise.Noise3D
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.

      • noise

        public static double noise(double xin,
                           double yin)
        2D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Parameters:
        xin - X input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        yin - Y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noise

        public static double noise(double x,
                           double y,
                           double z,
                           double w)
        4D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        w - W input (fourth-dimensional)
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noise

        public static double noise(double x,
                           double y,
                           double z,
                           double w,
                           int seed)
        4D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has veryf good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        w - W input (fourth-dimensional)
        seed - any int; will be used to completely alter the noise
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noiseAlt

        public static float noiseAlt(double x,
                             double y)
        2D simplex noise returning a float; extremely similar to noise(double, double), but this may be slightly faster or slightly slower. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method.
        Parameters:
        x - x input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        y - y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noiseAlt

        public static float noiseAlt(double x,
                             double y,
                             double z)
        3D simplex noise returning a float; extremely similar to noise(double, double, double), but this may be slightly faster or slightly slower. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double) and this method.
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive
